title: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel-group, 52-week Study Evaluating the Safety and Efficacy of Simufilam 100 mg Tablets in Subjects With Mild-to-Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: A 52-week safety and efficacy study of simufilam (PTI-125) given twice daily to participants with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease (AD) for 52 weeks. Approximately 750 participants will be randomized (1:1) to receive either placebo or 100 mg tablets of simufilam, twice daily, for 52 weeks. Clinic visits will occur 4 weeks after the baseline visit, and then every 12 weeks until the end of the study. The safety of simufilam, and its efficacy in enhancing cognition and slowing cognitive and functional decline will be evaluated.
description_detailed:
The primary objective of this study is to investigate the safety and efficacy of simufilam (PTI-125) in enhancing cognition and slowing cognitive and functional decline following 52-week, repeat-dose oral administration in participants with mild-to-moderate AD. Secondary objectives include the assessment of simufilam's effect on neuropsychiatric symptoms and caregiver burden. A third objective is to investigate the effect of simufilam treatment on plasma biomarkers. A limited number of research sites will be invited to participate in the pharmacokinetic (PK) and plasma biomarker sub-study. Collection of PK samples will enable an exposure-response analysis. Approximately 100 subjects will participate (50 per group). Plasma samples will be collected during the Screening Visit and again at Weeks 28 and 52. Change from Baseline for plasma biomarkers represent additional secondary endpoints.

Safety will be evaluated by adverse event monitoring, vital signs, clinical labs, and the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale at every visit. Subjects will undergo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) during screening to ensure entry criteria are met (unless recent MRI confirms entry criteria). Resting electrocardiograms will be conducted at Baseline (Study Day 1) and Weeks 4, 28, and 52. A complete physical and neurological examination will be performed at screening, and brief examinations will be performed at all other visits. Weight will be measured during the Screening Period, at Baseline (Study Day 1), and at all other visits.

An independent Data Safety Monitoring Board (DSMB) will meet periodically to review subject safety assessments and determine if dosing may continue. A charter will be developed with specific guidance for the DSMB.

groups.title: Simufilam 100 mg
groups.description:
Simufilam 100 mg, supplied by Cassava as coated tablets, and taken b.i.d. for 52 weeks

Simufilam: Simufilam is a novel drug candidate designed to treat and slow the progression of AD. Simufilam binds with femtomolar affinity to an altered conformation of filamin A that is present in the brain of patients with AD and critical to the toxicity of Aβ42. In this study, simufilam will be given b.i.d. for 52 weeks at a dose of 100 mg.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description:
Matching placebo, supplied by Cassava as coated tablets, and taken twice daily (b.i.d.) for 52 weeks

Placebo: Matching placebo given b.i.d. for 52 weeks.

classes.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the 12-item Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog12)
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to Week 52 in the ADAS-Cog12, a psychometrician-administered battery comprised of several cognitive domains including memory, comprehension, praxis, orientation, and spontaneous speech. Scores range from 0 (best) to 80 (worst).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are from subjects in the Intent-to-treat population (all randomized subjects) who completed the assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Activities of Daily Living (ADCS-ADL)
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to Week 52 in the ADCS-ADL, a 23-item study partner questionnaire that covers both basic activities of daily living (ADL) and more complex ADL or instrumental ADL. Scores range from 0 to 78, with a lower score indicating greater severity of functional loss.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are from subjects in the Intent-to-treat population (all randomized subjects) who completed the assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Integrated Alzheimer's Disease Rating Scale (iADRS)
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to Week 52 in the iADRS, where scores range from 0 to 146 with lower scores indicating worse performance.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are from subjects in the Intent-to-treat population (all randomized subjects) who completed the assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI)
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to Week 52 in the NPI, a 12-item study partner interview, which records the frequency and severity of common neuropsychiatric symptoms in dementia, as well as the level of study partner distress due to each of the neuropsychiatric problems. Scores range from 0 to 144, with higher scores indicating more frequent and severe symptoms, and greater levels of partner distress.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are from subjects in the Intent-to-treat population (all randomized subjects) who completed the assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE)
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to Week 52 in the MMSE, a set of standardized questions covering several target areas: orientation, registration, attention and calculation, short-term verbal recall, naming, repetition, 3-step command, reading, writing, and visuospatial cognitive assessment. Scores range from 0 to 30, lower scores indicate more severe impairment.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are from subjects in the Intent-to-treat population (all randomized subjects) who completed the assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Clinical Dementia Rating Sum of Boxes (CDR-SB)
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to Week 52 in the CDR-SB, which characterizes 6 domains of cognitive and functional performance applicable to AD and related dementias: memory, orientation, judgment and problem solving, community affairs, home and hobbies, and personal care. Scores for each domain have a minimum of 0 and a maximum of 3, and the 6 domain scores are summed to give the CDR-SB, which has a minimum score of 0 and a maximum score of 18. Higher scores indicate more severe impairment.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are from subjects in the Intent-to-treat population (all randomized subjects) who completed the assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Zarit Burden Interview (ZBI)
outcomeMeasures.description: The change from baseline to Week 52 in the ZBI, a 22-item study partner questionnaire designed to assess the stress or burden experienced by caregivers of people with dementia. Scores range from 0 to 88, with a higher score indicating greater stress or burden.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are from subjects in the Intent-to-treat population (all randomized subjects) who completed the assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes From Baseline in Plasma Biomarkers
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in the following plasma biomarkers of AD pathology, neurodegeneration, and neuroinflammation: phospho-tau217 (P-tau217), glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), neurofilament light chain (NfL), and total tau.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The overall number of participants analyzed is the number of participants who consented to take part in the biomarker analysis substudy and for whom there were baseline values for each biomarker. Plasma samples were not obtained from the whole substudy population at Week 52.

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes From Baseline in the Plasma SavaDx Biomarker
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in SavaDx, a novel plasma biomarker
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Change from baseline in SavaDx, a novel plasma biomarker, was included in the protocol as part of the secondary analysis as a biomarker which may have been measured. The final SAP, which postdated the protocol, included the analysis of biomarkers as an exploratory/tertiary endpoint. However, analysis of SavaDx was not conducted due to a sponsor decision and therefore, no results are available.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Up to 54 weeks after subjects took their first dose of study drug, or until resolution or stabilization of any AEs ongoing at the end of the study.
adverseEventsModule.description: Data are from the safety population, which included all subjects who received at least 1 dose of study drug.

certainAgreement.otherDetails: The Institution and PI must request review and comment of any proposed publication by the sponsor at least 90 days prior to submission of the publication. The sponsor will advise of any information which is confidential information or which may impair the sponsor's ability to obtain patent protection, and has the right to require confidential information or factual errors to be removed, or to delay the proposed publication by an additional 90 days to allow the sponsor to seek patent protection.

drug: Simufilam (PTI-125) — 100 mg oral tablet, proprietary small-molecule that binds altered filamin A
placebo: Matching placebo tablets, given twice daily (b.i.d.)
explanation_target: Reason: The protocol describes an investigational drug (simufilam, PTI-125) given orally twice daily for 52 weeks to slow cognitive and functional decline in mild-to-moderate Alzheimer’s disease — objectives consistent with a disease-modifying approach rather than only symptomatic relief. citeturn0search0

Act: Simufilam is described by the sponsor as a proprietary, oral small molecule that restores the normal shape/function of altered filamin A (FLNA) in the brain and is proposed to counteract Aβ42-related toxicity — i.e., it targets an Alzheimer’s-related molecular mechanism rather than being a biologic (antibody/vaccine) or a purely symptomatic cognitive enhancer. citeturn1search1turn0search0

Act — trial details (support): The clinical-trial registry entry and sponsor materials list the trial title, dosing (100 mg BID), randomization vs placebo, and primary aim to evaluate safety and efficacy for enhancing cognition and slowing decline. citeturn0search0turn1search5

Reflect: Given simufilam is a small molecule aimed at an AD-related target (altered filamin A) and the trial seeks to modify disease course (slowing cognitive/functional decline), the classification 'disease-targeted small molecule' best fits. There is some external context (late-stage trial results and program discontinuation reported publicly) but that does not change the drug type or trial intent. citeturn1news13turn1news15

Web-search results used (key sources): clinicaltrial registry summary for NCT04994483 describing the 52-week simufilam vs placebo study and objectives; Cassava Sciences press releases and corporate pages describing simufilam as a proprietary oral small molecule targeting filamin A; major news reports summarizing Phase 3 outcomes and program status. citeturn0search0turn1search1turn1search5turn1news13
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug simufilam (PTI‑125) is a proprietary oral small molecule that binds an altered conformation of the scaffolding protein filamin A (FLNA) in AD brain and is proposed to restore FLNA’s native shape and thereby block downstream toxic signaling (e.g., Aβ42 signaling via α7nAChR and TLR4). This target (altered FLNA) is not one of the CADRO-listed canonical targets (amyloid, tau, ApoE/lipids, neurotransmitter receptors, inflammation, proteostasis as usually defined, etc.), so it does not map cleanly to a named CADRO category. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: Key extracted facts from the trial description and literature — (1) the Phase 3 trial NCT04994483 evaluates simufilam 100 mg BID for 52 weeks in mild‑to‑moderate AD and explicitly describes simufilam as binding an altered conformation of filamin A (FLNA). citeturn1search0 (2) Peer‑reviewed publications and sponsor materials state simufilam’s mechanism is binding altered FLNA to disrupt FLNA’s aberrant interactions with receptors (α7nAChR, TLR4) that mediate Aβ42 toxicity and neuroinflammatory signaling. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Reflect: Because the drug’s immediate molecular target is filamin A (a scaffolding/cytoskeletal protein) rather than amyloid‑beta, tau, ApoE/lipids, or a canonical inflammatory enzyme/receptor, the most accurate CADRO classification is T) Other (novel/other target). One could note secondary pathway effects (reduction of Aβ42‑receptor signaling, downstream effects on tau phosphorylation and inflammation), but these are downstream consequences rather than the primary molecular target; they do not justify classifying the drug under Amyloid (A), Tau (B), or Inflammation (F) as the principal CADRO category. citeturn0search1turn0search5

Web search results used (key sources): clinical trial registry entry for NCT04994483 describing the 52‑week simufilam vs placebo study and target description; PubMed and MDPI publications describing PTI‑125/simufilam binding to altered filamin A and disrupting Aβ42‑α7nAChR/TLR4 signaling; Cassava Sciences materials summarizing simufilam’s mechanism and Phase 3 program. citeturn1search0turn0search0turn0search1turn0search4
